wikipedia_page.main: Margaret Furse (born Alice Margaret Watts, 18 February 1911 – 8 July 1974) was an English costume designer.

response: ** Margaret Furse, British Academy Award-winning costume designer for Anne of the Thousand Days (b. 1911)

link_mentions.page: Academy Award for Best Costume Design

response: Mary, Queen of Scots received five nominations at the 44th Academy Awards; Best Actress (Redgrave), Best Art Direction (Terence Marsh, Robert Cartwright, Peter Howitt), Best Costume Design (Margaret Furse), Best Original Dramatic Score, (John Barry), and Best Sound (Bob Jones, John Aldred).

Anderson enjoyed great commercial success with a series of plays set during the reign of the Tudor family, who ruled England, Wales and Ireland from 1485 until 1603. One play in particular – Anne of the Thousand Days – the story of Henry VIII's marriage to Anne Boleyn – was a hit on the stage in 1948, but did not reach movie screens for 21 years. It opened on Broadway starring Rex Harrison and Joyce Redman, and became a 1969 movie with Richard Burton and Geneviève Bujold. Margaret Furse won an Oscar for the film's costume designs.

response: *Anne of the Thousand Days – Margaret Furse

Roger Furse's first wife was Margaret Furse (nee Watts), who was also an Academy Award-winning costume designer. His portrait of her is included in the permanent collection of the National Portrait Gallery in London.
**The Mudlark – Edward Stevenson and Margaret Furse
The Mudlark was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Costume Design in a black-and-white film (Edward Stevenson and Margaret Furse).
